result.markdown:
--- title: "Box plot with ToothGrowth" author: "Sean Ahn" date: "2023-08-26" categories: [ggplot, visualization] image: "image.png" --- In this post, I've done a boxplot with ToothGrowth dataset. As you know, box plot is one of the most useful plot to visualize the dataset. But I don't explain what box plot. If you want to know what box plot is, you can see the [wiki](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Box_plot). ## Initializing I usually use the following code for initialization. If you don't want to remove plots and/or variables, you can skip it. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} graphics.off() rm(list = ls()) gc() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` used (Mb) gc trigger (Mb) limit (Mb) max used (Mb) Ncells 578462 30.9 1318111 70.4 NA 669274 35.8 Vcells 1056852 8.1 8388608 64.0 16384 1851504 14.2 ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} version ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` _ platform aarch64-apple-darwin20 arch aarch64 os darwin20 system aarch64, darwin20 status major 4 minor 3.1 year 2023 month 06 day 16 svn rev 84548 language R version.string R version 4.3.1 (2023-06-16) nickname Beagle Scouts ``` ::: ::: ## Loading Useful Library We want to use as few packages (some might call them "libraries") as possible. If possible, I'm going to use only the **tidyverse** package. [Tidyverse](https://www.tidyverse.org) is one of the most famous packages in R programming, and it's really powerful and useful. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} library(tidyverse) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` â”€â”€ Attaching core tidyverse packages â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€ tidyverse 2.0.0 â”€â”€ âœ” dplyr 1.1.2 âœ” readr 2.1.4 âœ” forcats 1.0.0 âœ” stringr 1.5.0 âœ” ggplot2 3.4.2 âœ” tibble 3.2.1 âœ” lubridate 1.9.2 âœ” tidyr 1.3.0 âœ” purrr 1.0.1 â”€â”€ Conflicts â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€ tidyverse_conflicts() â”€â”€ âœ– dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter() âœ– dplyr::lag() masks stats::lag() â„¹ Use the conflicted package () to force all conflicts to become errors ``` ::: ::: ## Select Dataset When I write posts in my blog, I use the built-in dataset because I don't want the reader to suffer by having to find the data from somewhere else. The dataset I'll be using in this post is shown below â¬‡ï¸ .
**The Effect of Vitamin C on Tooth Growth in Guinea Pigs** ### Description The response is the length of odontoblasts (cells responsible for tooth growth) in 60 guinea pigs. Each animal received one of three dose levels of vitamin C (0.5, 1, and 2 mg/day) by one of two delivery methods, orange juice or ascorbic acid (a form of vitamin C and coded as VC). ### Usage ToothGrowth ### Format A data frame with 60 observations on 3 variables. [,1] len numeric Tooth length. [,2] supp factor Supplement type (VC or OJ). [,3] dose numeric Dose in milligrams/day. As like other posts, I check what is in dataset and how big dataset is. Nothing special ğŸ˜ ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ToothGrowth |> head() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` len supp dose 1 4.2 VC 0.5 2 11.5 VC 0.5 3 7.3 VC 0.5 4 5.8 VC 0.5 5 6.4 VC 0.5 6 10.0 VC 0.5 ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ToothGrowth |> class() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] "data.frame" ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ToothGrowth |> dim() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 60 3 ``` ::: ::: ## Visualization All right! First of all, dataset copied into 'df' variable to preserve original data. It is fine for now because I work with built-in dataset. However, I strongly recommend copy if you work with your own dataset. It will help you saving time or work done properly. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} df <- ToothGrowth df |> head() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` len supp dose 1 4.2 VC 0.5 2 11.5 VC 0.5 3 7.3 VC 0.5 4 5.8 VC 0.5 5 6.4 VC 0.5 6 10.0 VC 0.5 ``` ::: ::: Now I make simple dotplot. it is hard to understand what data mean. but readers can notice there are distribution on something. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} df |> ggplot(aes(supp, len)) + geom_point() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](index_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-8-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: I overlay boxplot with dotplot. it can make readers understand easily because box plot shows lots of information graphically. (e.g median, first quartile, third quartile, etc.). ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} df |> ggplot(aes(supp, len)) + geom_boxplot(alpha = 0.5) + geom_point() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](index_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-9-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: I colored data respectively to distinguish easily. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} df |> ggplot(aes(supp, len, color = supp)) + geom_boxplot(alpha = 0.5, show.legend = FALSE) + geom_point() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](index_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-10-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: I replace to `geom_jitter()` because some of data is overplotting when I used `geom_point()`. It looks much better! ğŸ‘ ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} df |> ggplot(aes(supp, len, color = supp)) + geom_boxplot(alpha = 0.5, show.legend = FALSE) + geom_jitter(alpha = 0.7, width = 0.2) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](index_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-11-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: to make whisker on boxplot, I added `min` and `max` column with `mutate()` function. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} df1 <- df |> group_by(supp) |> mutate(min = min(len), max = max(len)) ``` ::: Then `goem_errorbar()` shows minimum value and maximum value as like below. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} df1 |> ggplot(aes(supp, len, color = supp)) + geom_boxplot(alpha = 0.5, show.legend = FALSE) + geom_errorbar(aes(ymin = min, ymax = max), alpha = 0.5) + geom_jitter(alpha = 0.7, width = 0.2) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](index_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-13-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: In fact, this boxplot is pretty good enough. To make the boxplot into a dose-dependent plot of tooth growth, I create a new variable named df2. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} df2 <- df |> group_by(supp, dose) |> mutate(min = min(len), max = max(len)) ``` ::: If I make the plot in the same way as before, and use the `facet_warp()` function to draw a boxplot by dose, I'll get something like this. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} df2 |> ggplot(aes(supp, len, color = supp)) + geom_boxplot(alpha = 0.5, show.legend = FALSE) + geom_errorbar(aes(ymin = min, ymax = max), alpha = 0.5) + geom_jitter(alpha = 0.7, width = 0.2) + facet_wrap(vars(dose)) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](index_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-15-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: All most done now. to specify what tab means, I change tab names with `labeller()` function. and I add an explanation in plot, decorate theme. I finally got it. ğŸº ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} dose_status <- c("0.5" = "0.5mg/day", "1" = "1.0mg/day", "2" = "2.0mg/day") ``` ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} df2 |> ggplot(aes(supp, len, color = supp)) + geom_boxplot(alpha = 0.5, show.legend = FALSE) + geom_errorbar(aes(ymin = min, ymax = max), alpha = 0.5) + geom_jitter(alpha = 0.7, width = 0.2) + facet_wrap(vars(dose), labeller = labeller(dose = dose_status)) + labs(title = "The Effect of Vitamin C on Tooth Growth in Guinea Pigs", subtitle = paste0("The response is the length of odontoblasts (cells responsible for tooth growth) in 60 guinea pigs.","\n", "Each animal received one of three dose levels of vitamin C (0.5, 1, and 2 mg/day)","\n", "by one of two delivery methods, orange juice or ascorbic acid (a form of vitamin C and coded as VC)."), x = "Supplement type", y = "Tooth length", color = "Supplement type") + theme_bw() + theme(legend.position = "bottom") ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](index_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-17-1.png){width=672} ::: :::
__END OF POST__
